titlestmt.titleproper:
Guide to the John B. Snook Architectural Record Collection
1843-1948
PR 64
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Kelema Moses

editionstmt.p: This version was derived from snook.xml

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2016-10-21T14:41-0400

did.unittitle: John B. Snook Architectural Record Collection
did.physloc: Department of Prints, Photographs, and Architectural Collections
did.abstract: The collection is comprised of ca. 2500 architectural drawings by John Butler Snook and his various firms.

custodhist.head: Provenance
custodhist.p: Gift of the estate of Thomas E. Snook, Jr., 1953.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: To view the architectural drawings in this collection, please contact the Print Room staff at least one week before anticipated visit, as drawings may need conservation.
Photocopying undertaken by staff only. Limited to twenty exposures of stable, unbound material per day. See guidelines in Print Room for details.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p:
Permission to reproduce any Print Room holdings through publication must be obtained from:
Rights and Reproductions
The New-York Historical Society
170 Central Park West
New York, NY 10024
Phone: (212) 873-3400 ext. 270
Fax: (212) 579-8794

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: This collection should be cited as: John B. Snook Architectural Record Collection, PR 064, Department of Prints, Photographs, and Architectural Collections, The New-York Historical Society.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: John Butler Snook (1815-1901) was born in England, and came to the United States as a child. His career as a practicing architect in New York City spanned nearly 60 years. He was educated as a carpenter, serving as an apprentice in his father's carpentry business, and was largely self-taught as an architect. In 1842 he joined the firm of Joseph Trench, and in less than five years he became the junior partner in the firm.

While associated with Trench, Snook designed the A. T. Stewart department store on lower Broadway, the first luxury dry-goods store in America, and the Metropolitan and St. Nicholas Hotels. After Trench moved west to San Francisco, Snook continued to work in New York City until the end of the century, focusing mainly on projects in the city, but also designing and constructing buildings in Brooklyn, the Bronx, Westchester County, and New Jersey.

Snook designed churches, hotels, residences, train depots, warehouses, tenements, and hospitals. While he did not specialize in one type of building, the majority of his work was in warehouses, commercial buildings, and tenements. In 1869, Cornelius Vanderbilt employed Snook to design the first Grand Central Depot, which was intended to serve as the main passenger terminal for the New York and Harlem Railroad and the New York Central and Hudson Railroad.

In 1836 Snook married Maria A. Weekes, with whom he had nine children that lived to adulthood. Three of these, James H., Samuel B., and Edward T., eventually joined his practice, which was renamed John B. Snook & Sons. One of Snook's sons-in-law, John W. Boylston, also worked in the firm. Snook died at his home in Brooklyn in 1901.

chronitem.event: Snook worked as a carpenter in partnership with William Beer, 328 Washington Street
Snook worked for Joseph Trench and Company at 12 Chambers Street
Trench and Snook at 12 Chambers Street
John B. Snook at 12 Chambers Street
John B. Snook & Sons at 12 Chambers Street
John B. Snook & Sons at 261 Broadway

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The John B. Snook Architectural Records Collection spans the period from 1843 to 1948 and contains architectural drawings and record books from John Butler Snook and his descendents' careers as architects in New York City. The collection is divided into two series: Architectural Drawings and Record Books.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Architectural drawings were arranged by size and then given project numbers. Most drawings are rolled and stored in boxes but a few have been flattened and are stored in folders. Projects are listed by client name, if known, and then by project name and address.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material at the New-York Historical Society
relatedmaterial.p: Volumes from John B. Snook's library can be found in the New-York Historical Society's Library. Snook's trade sign from 1847 is held by the N-YHS Museum.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Material
separatedmaterial.p: Volumes from John B. Snook's library can be found in the New-York Historical Society's Library. Snook's trade sign from 1847 is held by the N-YHS Museum.

did.unittitle: Series I: Architectural Drawings

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Series I. Architectural Drawings contains a total of 2,719 drawings representing 225 different projects. Drawings include elevations, plans, sections, mechanical and engineering drawings, blueprints, working drawings, and presentation drawings. The majority of the projects found here are buildings in New York City and surrounding boroughs and towns. Most projects represented are generally those from later in Snook's career. A few projects date from the time of John Snook Sons, the firm's name after Snook's death. Snook's design for the original Grand Central Terminal is only represented here by one large elevation, probably a presentation drawing.

Projects are arranged by size of drawing, and are numbered accordingly for easy reference. The numbers were assigned by the N-YHS staff and do not reflect any intention on the part of the architect. All drawings for the same project are rolled together, unless some of the drawings required flat storage. A list of projects by geographical location, and by date, follow this finding aid.

The architectural drawings were surveyed and inventoried in the summer of 2004. Those that could not be unrolled were humidified and flattened. Remaining rolled drawings are extremely fragile and may need conservation before being viewed. Please contact the Print Room staff at least one week before anticipated visit. Also, the collection was not processed per se, as there remains a great deal of research to be done on each building.

odd.head: General note

did.unittitle: Series II: Financial Records

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Series II. Business Records includes 37 bound volumes, all but one are some form of financial and business records. One bound "Index to drawings by John B, Snook and John B. Snook & Sons" lists projects and drawings, but it can be difficult to match these to the projects for which drawings are available.
